title: NICE NG59: Low Back Pain Exercise Guidelines
snippet: Exercise therapy should be considered for people with low back pain, with or without sciatica. A structured exercise programme should include activities to improve physical fitness (aerobic capacity, muscle strength and flexibility).
source: NICE Guideline NG59 (2016) - Low back pain and sciatica

title: NICE NG59: Self-Management for Low Back Pain
snippet: Advise people with low back pain to stay physically active and continue with normal daily activities. Bed rest is not recommended as a treatment for low back pain.
source: NICE Guideline NG59 (2016) - Low back pain and sciatica

title: AAOS ACL Injury: Range of Motion Priority
snippet: Early range of motion exercises are recommended following ACL injury to prevent joint stiffness. Full knee extension should be achieved as soon as tolerated, typically within the first 1-2 weeks.
source: AAOS Clinical Practice Guideline: ACL Injuries (2022)

title: AAOS ACL Injury: Quadriceps Strengthening
snippet: Quadriceps strengthening exercises should begin early in rehabilitation. Progressive resistance training helps restore muscle strength and function following ACL injury.
source: AAOS Clinical Practice Guideline: ACL Injuries (2022)

title: APTA Low Back Pain: Movement-Based Classification
snippet: Treatment should be matched to patient classification. Movement-based approaches focus on specific directional preferences and movement impairments to guide exercise selection.
source: APTA Clinical Practice Guidelines: Low Back Pain (2021)

title: Normal Knee Range of Motion
snippet: Normal knee flexion ranges from 0° (full extension) to approximately 130-140° of flexion. Functional activities typically require 90-120° of knee flexion.
source: Normative Range of Motion Reference (Reese & Bandy, 2017)

title: Normal Shoulder Flexion Range
snippet: Normal shoulder flexion ranges from 0° to 150-180°. Overhead activities typically require at least 120° of shoulder flexion for functional movement.
source: Normative Range of Motion Reference (Reese & Bandy, 2017)

title: Normal Hip Flexion Range
snippet: Normal hip flexion ranges from 0° to approximately 120-125°. Hip flexion is essential for activities like sitting, squatting, and stair climbing.
source: Normative Range of Motion Reference (Reese & Bandy, 2017)

title: Sit-to-Stand Functional Importance
snippet: The sit-to-stand movement is a fundamental functional activity requiring coordinated hip, knee, and ankle movement. It's essential for independence in daily activities.

title: Sit-to-Stand Biomechanics
snippet: Successful sit-to-stand requires adequate knee extension strength, hip flexion mobility, and ankle dorsiflexion. The movement involves forward trunk lean followed by hip and knee extension.
source: Biomechanical Analysis of Sit-to-Stand (Schenkman et al., 1990)

title: Exercise Safety Principles
snippet: Exercise should be performed within comfortable limits. Stop if you experience sharp pain, dizziness, or unusual discomfort. Gradual progression is key to safe exercise participation.

title: Exercise Progression Principles
snippet: Progressive overload should be applied gradually through increases in repetitions, duration, or range of motion. Allow adequate recovery time between exercise sessions.

title: Pain Monitoring During Exercise
snippet: Some mild discomfort during exercise is normal, but sharp or severe pain is not. Use a 0-10 pain scale: exercise should not increase pain beyond 3-4/10 during activity.

title: Benefits of Knee Flexion Exercises
snippet: Knee flexion exercises help maintain joint mobility, strengthen surrounding muscles, and prevent stiffness. Regular movement promotes joint health and functional capacity.

title: Benefits of Shoulder Flexion Exercises
snippet: Shoulder flexion exercises improve overhead reach capacity, maintain joint mobility, and strengthen the shoulder complex. Important for daily activities like reaching and lifting.

title: Movement Quality vs Quantity
snippet: Focus on controlled, quality movement rather than speed or excessive repetitions. Proper form reduces injury risk and maximizes exercise benefits.

title: Managing Exercise Fatigue
snippet: Recognize signs of fatigue including decreased coordination, increased effort, or form breakdown. Rest when needed and avoid exercising through excessive fatigue.

title: Exercise Consistency Benefits
snippet: Regular, consistent exercise is more beneficial than sporadic intense sessions. Aim for frequent, moderate exercise rather than infrequent vigorous activity.

title: Individual Exercise Responses
snippet: Exercise responses vary between individuals based on factors like age, fitness level, and medical history. Programs should be individualized to personal capabilities and goals.

title: When to Seek Professional Guidance
snippet: Consult a healthcare provider or physical therapist if you experience persistent pain, have specific medical conditions, or need personalized exercise recommendations.
